comment._content: Flat tyre! the technical term is "Wheel Loss Incident"

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Is this vehicle in your guide books?

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Carol looks like BM1606 but could be 1506?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Thanks Bill! Overlooked this one today, sorry [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abaraphobia] ! But I'm thinking that might not be an Irish reg no. at all, despite all the Irish tourist place names on the front. Wonder what happened to the front wheel?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
The front wheel hasn't been put on properly so vibration will have undone the nuts and the wheel has fallen off - it doesnt look like a puncture but it's strange there is no sign of the wheel at all! 

BM was a registration series issued for vehicles from Birmingham but before partition it could have been used in Ireland. So it was probably a second hand vehicle.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abaraphobia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Hello, you two! Finally making good on my promise to upload a higher res version. As Bill says, BM is an English reg, so I can't help with my magic books... But nice to be able to zoom in on this one, as it turns out that it's yet another Luton Commer Car that had been put to use for tourists in Ireland!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] The first Commer buses were made at the Luton factory in 1909, which narrows things down a bit!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abaraphobia] Throwing out 1910 with loads of question marks then... Really down to British reg. nos. - BM 1606!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: Here's a 1909 model that's still knocking around! -

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abaraphobia] Swit Swoo! I wonder if "ours" were painted in such jaunty colours?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: According to www.cvpg.co.uk/REG.pdf, BM was Luton, which is where Commers were made from 1906 on.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 46477046@N08
comment._content: Don't you think the vehicle will have come to a sudden stop and the (released) wheel will have rolled quietly on ahead and is probably lying just out of shot to the left.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/akoura] Found this one. The wheel is behind...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
Looks like the front axle broke rather than the wheel falling off then! The ladies don't look very happy - especially at being "papped"!

Apart from the signage on the bus, you can tell this wasn't Northern Ireland by the fact that no one had set fire to the bus blocking the road!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: You can see the advertised places on a coach route on this 1906 railway map. As well as being scenic, the route links the GS&W at Killarney to the Cork, Bandon and South Coast railway at Bantry.
